Specified System: 1.1

 

AUTOMATIC SYSTEMS FOR FIRE SUPPRESSION

SPRINKLER SYSTEM

(Performance Standards: NZS 4541:2013, NZS 4515:2009, NFPA 25)

 

 

Type:

Make:

 

A. Inspections

Automatic sprinkler and drencher systems shall be inspected regularly to ensure continued effective operation as is appropriate for the installation.

 

Frequency of inspection is dependent upon the type of installation, and shall be weekly, monthly, quarterly, annually, two yearly and four yearly as prescribed in the relevant referenced Standard.

B. Maintenance

Automatic sprinkler systems and drencher systems shall be maintained in accordance with NZS 4541 or NZS 4515 as is appropriate for the installation.

Planned preventative and responsive maintenance required to ensure that the system will operate as required in the event of fire.

 

Defects shall be remedied immediately that they become apparent.

 

 

C. Persons responsible

An independent qualified person shall undertake the above inspection and maintenance procedures.

 

 

D. Records

Records must be stored at the control valves of the system, retained for a period of two years, and include:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken to repair or maintain the system

v. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

vi. Name of person undertaking inspection

ConditionTitle: Gas foam flood, deluge system, dry + wet fire extinguishing system
ConditionText:
Specified System 1.2

 

AUTOMATIC SYSTEMS FOR FIRE SUPPRESSION

GAS AND FOAM FLOOD OR DELUGE SYSTEMS, DRY AND WET FIRE

EXTINGUISHING SYSTEMS

(Performance Standards: NZS 4541:2013, NZS 4515:2009, NFPA 25)

 

Type:

Make:

 

A. Inspections

National Fire Protection Association Standards:

The content and frequency of inspections shall be in accordance with the standard applicable to the system installation.

 

The following standards are considered appropriate for inspection and maintenance of gas or foam flood or deluge systems, or for dry or wet chemical extinguishing systems:

11 Low Expansion Foam (2002 Edition)

11A Medium and High Expansion Foam Systems (1999 Edition)

12 Carbon Dioxide Extinguishing Systems (2000 Edition)

12A Halon 1301 Fire Extinguishing Systems (2004 Edition)

16 Instillation of Foam - Water Sprinkler and Foam Water Spray Systems (2003 Edition)

17 Dry Chemical Extinguishing Systems (2002 Edition)

17A Wet Chemical Extinguishing Systems (2002 Edition)

 

Inspections shall be monthly and annually, or as required by the relevant standard if this is more stringent. Gas storage cylinders shall be tested and maintained in accordance with the Dangerous Goods Regulations (Class II - Gases) 1980 Parts 1 & 2.

 

 

B. Maintenance

Planned preventative and responsive maintenance required to ensure that the system will operate as required in the event of fire. Defects shall be remedied immediately they become apparent.

 

 

C. Persons responsible

An independent qualified person shall undertake the above inspection and maintenance procedures.

 

 

D. Records

Records must be stored at the control valves of the system, retained for a period of two years, and include:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken to repair or maintain the system

v. The standard used for inspection and maintenance

vi. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

vii. Name of person undertaking inspection

ConditionTitle: Automatic or manual emergency warning systems
SearchTerm: Automatic or manual emergency warning systems SS2 BC CS Specified Systems BC0004

ConditionTitle: Automatic or manual fire alarm systems
ConditionText:
Specified System: 2.1

 

MANUAL OR AND AUTOMATIC EMERGENCY WARNING SYSTEMS

FOR FIRE OR OTHER DANGERS

MANUAL AND AUTOMATIC FIRE ALARMS; SMOKE AND HEAT DETECTORS;

GAS; RADIATION SYSTEMS

(Performance Standards: NZS 4512:2010, AS 1851:2005, NFPA 25)

 

Type:

Make:

 

A. Inspections

Emergency warning systems shall be inspected regularly to ensure continued effective operation. Content of the inspections for the different inspection frequencies shall be in accordance with the above referenced standards:

i. Automatic and manual fire alarms monthly, annually NZS 4512, NZS 4515, AS 1851

 

Note: Where old and new systems are combined each part of the system shall be maintained and inspected to the standard relevant at time of installation.

 

ii. Voice communication systems monthly, six monthly AS 2220 and AS 1851

 

 

B. Maintenance

Planned preventative and responsive maintenance required to ensure that the system will operate as required in the event of fire or other danger. Defects shall be remedied immediately that they become apparent.

 

 

C. Persons responsible

An independent qualified person shall undertake the above inspection and maintenance procedures.

 

 

D. Records

Records must be retained for a period of two years, on the premises, or any other location agreed to with Auckland Council and includes:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken to repair or maintain the system

v. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

vi. Name of person undertaking inspection

ConditionTitle: Automatic gas leak detection systems for the detection and measurement of combustible gases
ConditionText:
Specified System: 2.2

MANUAL OR AUTOMATIC EMERGENCY WARNING SYSTEMS FOR FIRE OR OTHER DANGERS

AUTOMATIC GAS LEAK DETECTION SYSTEMS FOR THE DETECTION AND

MEASUREMENT OF COMBUSTIBLE GASES

(Performance Standards: NZS 5263:2003)

 

Type:

Make:

 

A. Inspections

Gas detection systems shall be inspected for compliance with NZS 5263 or other recognised national standards. In no case shall the period between calibrations of the gas detection apparatus exceed 6 months.

 

 

B. Maintenance

Planned preventative and responsive maintenance required to ensure that the system will operate as required in the event of an emergency. Refer to Door Inspections Guide (attached)

 

 

B. Maintenance

Planned preventative and responsive maintenance should be carried out in accordance with the performance inspection standard or documents to ensure:

 

Safe suitable operation and those occupants are not prevented from leaving the building in the event of an emergency, and that people with disabilities can gain access to the internal space of the building.

 

All defects shall be remedied immediately that they become apparent.

 

 

C. Persons responsible

Daily and monthly inspections shall be undertaken by the owner; annual inspections and maintenance shall be undertaken by an independent qualified person

 

 

D. Records

Records must be retained for a period of two years, on the premises, or any other location agreed to with Auckland Council and includes:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken to repair or maintain the system

v. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

vi. Name of person undertaking inspection

Specified system: 3.2

 

ELECTROMAGNETIC OR AUTOMATIC DOORS OR WINDOWS

ACCESS CONTROLLED DOORS

Includes: Doors that have security control measure installed on or as part of it

E.g., swipe card, keypad and sensor-delayed egress

(Performance Standards: NZS 4239:1993)

 

The owner is required to provide Auckland Council with an inspection and maintenance schedule to ensure the proper operation of the device, alternatively the following maintenance guidelines apply when applicable.

 

A. Inspections

Visual daily, monthly (recorded) six-monthly and annual inspections for purpose group crowd activity

Monthly (recorded) six-monthly and annual inspections for all other occupancies

All defects shall be remedied immediately that they become apparent.

 

 

C. Person responsible

Daily and monthly inspection shall be undertaken by the owner.

Six-monthly and annual inspection and maintenance shall be undertaken by an independent qualified person

 

 

D. Records

Records must be retained for a period of two years, on the premises, or any other location agreed to with Auckland Council and includes:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken to repair or maintain the system

v. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

vi. Name of person undertaking inspection

All defects shall be remedied immediately that they become apparent.

 

 

C. Person responsible

Daily and monthly inspections shall be undertaken by the owner; annual inspection and maintenance shall be undertaken by an independent qualified person

 

 

D. Records

Records must be retained for a period of two years, on the premises, or any other location agreed to with Auckland Council and includes:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken to repair or maintain the system

v. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

vi. Name of person undertaking inspection

Specified System: 4

 

EMERGENCY LIGHTING SYSTEMS

(Performance Standards: AS/NZS 2293.2:1995, NZS 6104:1981)

 

A. Inspections

Inspections of emergency lighting systems installed prior to 1995 shall be fortnightly or monthly (depending on type of installation), and annually, with inspection content being in accordance with NZS6742 for the inspection frequency.

 

Emergencylighting systems installed after 1995 shall be inspected six monthly and annually to the requirements of AS/NZS 2293.

Uninterrupted power supply inspections for emergency lighting must be to the satisfaction of designer / manufacture or installation engineer.

 

 

B. Maintenance

Planned preventative and responsive maintenance required to ensure that the system will operate as required in the event of usual power supply. Systems installed after 1995 shall be maintained in accordance with AS/NZS 2293.

 

Where there are no appropriate procedures in AS/NZS 2293, an inspection and reporting system must be submitted to Auckland Council for its approval. Defects shall be remedied immediately that they become apparent.

 

 

C. Persons responsible

Systems installed in accordance with AS/NZS 2293 shall be inspected six monthly by an independent qualified person.

 

 

D. Records

Records must be retained for a period of two years, on the premises, or any other location agreed to with Auckland Council and includes:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken to repair or maintain the system

v. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

vi. Name of person undertaking inspection

Specified System: 5

 

ESCAPE ROUTE PRESSURISATION SYSTEMS

(Performance Standards: AS 1668.1:1998, AS 1851.6:2012)

 

 

A. Inspections

Escape route including corridor or lift shaft pressurisation systems shall be inspected regularly to ensure continued effective operation. Inspection content shall be in accordance with AS 1851 and or AS 1668.1 or the designer's recommendations as is appropriate for the installation.

is not obstructed by curtains or drapes.

 

 

B. Maintenance

Planned preventative and responsive maintenance required to ensure that the system will operate as required in the event of fire. Such shall be maintained in accordance with above standards or the designer's recommended maintenance procedures, as is appropriate.

 

Defects shall be remedied immediately that they become apparent.

 

 

C. Persons responsible

An independent qualified person shall undertake the above inspection and maintenance procedures.

 

 

D. Records

Records must be retained for a period of two years, on the premises, or any other location agreed to with Auckland Council and includes:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken

v. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

vi. Name of person undertaking inspection

Specified System: 6

B. Maintenance

Planned preventative and responsive maintenance required to ensure that the system will operate as required in the event of fire. Riser mains for Fire Service use shall be maintained in accordance with NZS 4510 and in addition to below.

 

Defects shall be remedied immediately that they become apparent.

 

 

C. Persons responsible

Monthly inspection of hydrants to detect obvious faults or damage shall be undertaken by the owner, (or owner's authorised agent).

An independent qualified person shall undertake all other inspection and maintenance procedures.

 

 

D. Records

Records must be retained for a period of two years, on the premises, or any other location agreed to with Auckland Council and includes:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken to repair or maintain the system

v. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

vi. Name of person undertaking inspection

Specified System: 7

 

AUTOMATIC BACK-FLOW PREVENTERS CONNECTED TO

A POTABLE WATER SUPPLY

(Performance Standards: AS 2845.1:2010, AS 2845.3:2010, AS/NZS 3500.1:2003)

 

 

Location:

 

A. Inspections

Automatic back-flow preventers connected to a potable water supply shall be inspected and tested annually in accordance with Chapter 5 of the United States Environmental Protection Agency or Australian Standard AS 2845: Part 3.

 

Where non-testable back-flow preventers are used in accordance with AS/NZS 3500.1 they shall be inspected annually and replaced if leaking or displaying any other fault. (Under AS/NZS 3500.1, non-testable back-flow preventers are permitted only in a zone downstream of a zone testable device.)

 

 

B. Maintenance

Planned preventative and responsive maintenance required to ensure that the system will operate as required to ensure continued safe and effective operation in providing protection to potable water supply. Automatic back-flow preventers shall be immediately repaired or replaced if they fail the inspection test and re-tested after repair or replacement.

 

Other back-flow prevention devices shall be maintained in their original state.

 

 

C. Persons responsible

An independent qualified person shall undertake the above inspection and maintenance procedures.

 

 

D. Records

Records must be retained for a period of two years, on the premises, or any other location agreed to with Auckland Council and includes:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken

v. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

Name of person undertaking inspection

Specified System: 8.1

 

LIFTS, ESCALATORS, TRAVELATORS OR OTHER SYSTEMS FOR MOVING PEOPLE OR GOODS WITHIN BUILDINGS

PASSENGER CARRYING LIFTS

(Performance Standards: NZS 4332:1997 NZS 4334:2012 EN 81:2003)

 

A. Inspections

Passenger carrying lift installations shall be inspected annually. Installations in existing buildings shall comply with the Power Lift Rules applicable at the time of installation. Where the installation complies with D2/AS1 (lift design based on NZS 4332 or NZS 4334), Inspections and checks shall be carried out in accordance with the attached list.

 

If D2/AS1 has not been used the owner shall nominate the necessary lift inspections. Such proposals shall be to the approval of the Auckland City Council.

The tests of clause D.2 shall be performed in such a manner that, despite their repetition, they do not cause excessive wear or impose stresses likely to reduce the safety of the lift. This is the case in particular of the tests on components such as the safety gear and the buffers, tests on these components shall be carried out with an empty car and at reduced speed.

B. Maintenance

Planned preventative and responsive maintenance required to ensure that the system will operate as required in the event of fire to ensure continued safe and effective operation. Lifts shall be maintained in accordance with the manufacturer or supplier's recommendations. Where such instructions are not available, maintenance shall be in accordance with a schedule prepared by a person who, on the basis of experience and qualifications, is competent to determine lift maintenance requirements.

 

Maintenance frequency shall reflect the rate of lift usage, but in no case shall it be at greater than 6 monthly intervals. For heavy usage, the maintenance could be fortnightly.

 

 

C. Persons responsible

An independent qualified person shall undertake the above inspection and maintenance procedures.

 

 

D. Records

Records must be retained for a period of two years, on the premises, or any other location agreed to with Auckland Council and includes:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken to repair or maintain the system

v. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

vi. Name of person undertaking inspection/maintenance

Specified System: 8.2

 

LIFTS, ESCALATORS, TRAVELATORS OR OTHER SYSTEMS FOR MOVING PEOPLE OR GOODS WITHIN BUILDINGS

GOODS OR SERVICE LIFTS

(Performance Standards: NZS 4332:1997 EN 81:2003)

 

 

A. Inspections

Service lift installations shall be inspected annually. Installations in existing buildings shall comply with the Rules for Power Lifts not exceeding 750 Watts (1.H.P) applicable at the time of installation. Where the lift installation complies with D2/AS2 the attached checklist is a suitable basis for the inspection. If D2/AS2 has not been used the owner should provide and work to a similar checklist approved by Auckland Council.

 

 

B. Maintenance

Planned preventative and responsive maintenance required to ensure that the system will operate as required to ensure continued safe and effective operation. Lifts shall be maintained in accordance with the manufacturer or supplier's recommendations but at least every six months.

 

 

C. Persons responsible

An independent qualified person shall undertake the above inspection and maintenance procedures.

 

 

D. Records

Records must be retained for a period of two years, on the premises, or any other location agreed to with Auckland Council and includes:

i. Date of inspection

ii. Type of inspection

iii. Any repairs or maintenance found to be required

iv. Action taken to repair or maintain the system

v. The system inspected complies with the requirements of the compliance schedule

vi. Name of person undertaking inspection

 

 

 

 

 

CHECKLIST SUITABLE FOR GOODS LIFTS COMPLYING WITH D2/AS2

System Description Reference

Machinery spaces

Visual inspection of machine beams and supports 3.1(a)

Check security of machine room door 3.2(f)*

Check lighting in the machinery space functions 3.2(d)

Check the condition of the controller

Check the governor and any position devices

Check for the presence of circuit diagrams, manual and log

book

Check the condition and operation of the brake and the condition of brake linings 3.1(b)

Check the running of the lift machinery

Check condition of drive belts 3.1(c)

Lift well Inspect and test any safety gear 1.5

Visual check of lift well enclosure 5

Check hoisting ropes for equal tension, attachments and terminations correct and in good condition, number of broken wires within acceptable limits, fillings not being shed, all ropes of similar condition, correct length of rope 6.1.1

Visual check of guide rails for integrity, straightness and security 9.2*

Check condition of guide shoes or rollers

Lift pit Remove any rubbish from the lift pit

Check lighting in the pit functions 4.4(g)

Check dryness of pit 4.4(b)

Visual check of buffer condition and other pit components 4.3*

Landing stations Check door locks 8.3(a) and (b), 8.4

Check lift controls for correct operation

Lift car Check car doors or safety barriers

Check lift car lighting

Hydraulic systems Visual check of the hydraulic system, including hoses, ram and cylinder 12*

Check caisson for moisture

Check operation of anti-creep device 12.7

Check the operation of control and auxiliary valves 12.8, 12.9

Operation Check operation of terminal stopping devices, slack rope switch and any emergency switch 10

Check landing door interlocks and opening of the door when the car is away from the landing 8.4(a)

General

Visually check for any repairs or modifications carried out

Maintain full records of maintenance and inspections
